commentBody: TOTALLYDONE with this puzzle. Pretty easy.
Another fun one. Liked the theme. Thanks, Joe! Y‚Äôall have a great Tuesday!

In the entire corpus of medieval Icelandic literature, there are only two so-called Eddas: 1) the "younger" Edda of Snorri Sturluson, which is a poetic ‚Äî a manual for poets; and 2) the "elder" Edda, a collection of short narrative poems written in alliterative verse. Sagas, of which there are many extant, are lengthy prose narratives similar to the modern novel. "Saga" and "Edda" are not synonymous.

I, too, side- eye REUNES. Don't mind NEONATE as much, though I can't recall if my familiarity is because crossword or if it's  something I encounter irl (neonatal being the more common form). 

Bet there will be grumbling in comments, said I, as soon as I had that filled. Didn't expect grumbling in column, lol!

I finished this pretty quickly but somehow it felt like a crunchier Tuesday. Only 8 three letter words. For some reason I didn‚Äôt guess the theme until the end although it should have been obvious‚ÄîI was leaning toward guessing it was a common word before or after since I saw TOP and DOWN. Once I got it I thought these were great theme choices.  Seems like Mondays and Tuesdays have become more polished and interesting lately. I really enjoyed the clue for INTERN.
Terrible
Yeah, let‚Äôs not make ‚Äúreune‚Äù happen.
Not sure about 39A but otherwise nice and neat. An enjoyable and quick Tuesday puzzle.

Pretty good puzzle, mostly easy.  I finished in 9:41 which might be my Tuesday PB but I don't know because when I was on vacation and playing with crappy Wifi they set my Tuesday PB to like 3 minutes and I can't get them to remove that result.

I had a few squares I needed to fix at the end.  First, I had LAO TSU instead of LAO TZU so didn't realize it might be AZTEC until later and have never heard of CLIO awards.  Then since I had OATS and not OATY I didn't realize it was wrong until I had all the other crossing clues for TOKYO DOME.

And yeah REUNES makes no sense, nobody shortens it that way.  But most of the puzzle was like a slightly harder than average Monday.
I am truly embarrassed that my original answer to 24A, from the crosses, was osTEC.

Actually, Sam, the conventional ‚Äî I won‚Äôt say only ‚Äî meaning of C.O.D. ‚Äî is ‚Äúcash on delivery‚Äù.  Of course, it won‚Äôt be long ‚Äî maybe we are already there ‚Äî before people will say, ‚ÄúCash?  What is that?‚Äù
Now I have an earworm for "On Board", which has the line "I'm a flotsam jetsam mess, a drunken sailor in a dress" https://youtu.be/OS3Hi2gge3U?si=hT2OtcdakXcp5ekl
Reune is jejune.

My responses to REUNES, ETERNE, and NEONATE are quite different:

REUNES:  I know that it's a well-established word that goes back more than a century, but I think it sounds like corporate speak.  I have never heard anyone ever say this in real life.  If someone said they were reuning, I think they'd get the Gen Z Stare from me

ETERNE:  another legitimate word, but something no one has said in centuries.  A sign that the constructor is reaching in order to fill this section of the grid

NEONATE:  a standard term that's used by doctors every day

Can I carp too, about my own areas of (what passes for) expertise?

Trigonometry is all about ratios.  Yes, COSINE is a ratio, but so are secant, cosecant, sine, tangent, and cotangent.  

I don't think that makes the clue invalid.  Simply that you have to use crosses to distinguish between COSINE and secant (in this case).
That was a really good fill! A few red herrings here and there and some intelligent clues. Loved it.

4 minutes exactly below my average Tuesday. But had to get a lot of clues with crosses. Wanted Cher instead of Jlo but REALID Fell in easy. Thought MUESLI was developed in eastern Europe but that was easy. TOKYODOME wasn‚Äôt a gimme but came quickly

I'm gonna object to the use of "comprise" in the clue for the theme revealer while I send my thanks to Sam for using it correctly.
And before Barry Ancona links to Merriam Webster with its snarky summary of the dispute, I'll just say this: either the whole comprises the parts (music to the ears) or the parts comprise the whole (ew!)--you can't have it both ways!

"'Grass, leaves, spider webs'...what's this?"
"Oh, just my to-dew list."

(Just had to drop in with that one.)
TOTALLYDOABLE
Crunchy Tuesday for me.  Was never in jeopardy, but much longer to solve than my usual Tuesday these days.  NW corner gave a run.

Nora EPHRON makes me think of all of her Meg Ryan movies‚Ä¶When Harry Met Sally, Sleepless in Seattle, and You‚Äôve Got Mail. 
The ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have what she‚Äôs having‚Äù scene in When Harry Met Sally is iconic. I considered Ms EPHRON the Queen of the Rom-Com. She is truly missed
Clever theme with decent fill (other than REUNES). Thanks, Joe m, you Top Dog, you. üòä

This was quite an enjoyable puzzle. Unusually for an early week grid, the realization of the theme actually helped me solve it, as I was completely clueless about TOKYO DOME.

I ran into the bug people sometimes experience - even though I completed the puzzle and got the related popup, the timer keeps running and my only option is to reset the grid. What is that email for support? I can't find it anywhere in the app.
This is a crispy and fun Tuesday. Well played!

I call this a tasty Tuesday, and it does check all the boxes.  

Thank you, Joe.  Can I have another one?
Just here to similarly register disapproval of REUNES and ETERNE. NEONATE does actually exist in the real word.

If I was teaching English to a non-English speaker and they said REUNES I would say ‚Äúsorry that‚Äôs wrong, it should be ‚Äòreunites‚Äô‚Äù. 

If they then showed me it in a dictionary I would say ‚ÄúTrust me. It may be in the dictionary (and I should mention in passing that I‚Äôm impressed by your use of NEONATE, which *is* a word) but nobody ever said ‚Äúreune‚Äù and if you say it people will think you don‚Äôt speak English well.‚Äù

Yes, REUNES is that bad.

Raise your hand if you have ever in your entire life (before now) said REUNE, or heard anyone say REUNE.  
Like maybe, " I think the old crowd should reune sometime," 
or "Are you going to the high school reunion?  I'm just dying to REUNE!"
I stubbornly tried to fit G Major √Æn even though it seemed unlikely for various crosses. Other than that it was a smooth, enjoyable ride.

I'm a NEWBIE but breezed through his one. 

I could agree with Wordplay about REUNES or ETERNE, but I think NEONATE is a very nice legitimate appropriate word. 

From the internet:

ne¬∑o¬∑nate
/Àànƒì…ôÀånƒÅt/
nountechnical
a newborn child (or other mammal).
Medicine
an infant less than four weeks old.
Nice Tuesday! That southwest corner though üòÆ‚Äçüí®
EDDA of EDDY: what a guy, makes you cry, und EDU.

I am usually one not to crow, but I‚Äôm bursting with joy and I can‚Äôt hold it in.

Some of you know that I like to leave the revealer blank, fill in the theme answers, and, without reading the revealer‚Äôs clue, try to guess it ‚Äì a skill I‚Äôm weak at.  Occasionally I report coming close, maybe figuring out the reveal after finally reading its clue, or after having filled in a few letters.

But today, after filling in three of the four theme answers my brain saw it and shouted ‚ÄúTO DO LIST!‚Äù  I plugged it in, and it worked!  It worked!

Now maybe this was an easy revealer to thusly crack, but I do not care.  As I sublimely float, thinking that maybe, just maybe, I‚Äôm getting better at this, I will not accept any naysaying. La la la la la la la.  And woo-hoo!

Thank you for your attention to this matter.
A swell Tuesday!
agree wholeheartedly on REUNE!!!! Wanted a rebus......and it's cold in Prince Edward Island too!!!!! Jim
731. I thought yesterday made two years but forgot Leap Day.

Wow, I completely missed that this puzzle even had a theme until I read it in the blog. SMH
Fortunately it wasn't required to solve the puzzle, but still..

That was my 25th Tuesday in a row, despite that SW corner! This had just the right amount of crunch, with some obscure but solvable answers (the ones everyone is talking about). I wonder why Joe left no constructor‚Äôs notes. That seems unusual to me.

And I love any mention of Nora Ephron! She is a rom-com genius! ‚ÄúSleepless in Seattle‚Äù was our first-date movie! (We were supposed to see ‚ÄúThe Fugitive,‚Äù but it was sold out. I had seen ‚ÄúSleepless‚Äù the week before with my family, and sheepishly suggested it, not knowing how much my future hubby would love it. We were MFEO. IYKYK. ‚ù§Ô∏èüòä

This grid has 70 words, more typical of a Friday puzzle, and yet it solves like a Tuesday, which goes to show how important the cluing is to a puzzle‚Äôs difficulty.  I believe Joe nailed the cluing ‚Äì keeping it Tuesday-easy yet not embarrassingly easy.  

For instance, [Fancy] for DESIRE, where I wasn‚Äôt sure of the answer from the clue, but with a couple of crosses, it was obvious.  

Enhancing my solve were a passel of words I like, old friends that I don‚Äôt run into that often: SIEVES, MUESLI, SUTURE, JETSAM, STOKES, TINKERER, LOBO.  

It‚Äôs a tight theme, though there are a few other possibilities, like TOUCH DOWN, TOY DOG, and TOFU DOG.  So, credit to Joe for coming up with an answer set that met the requirements of symmetry.

The image that the dook of SENT COD elicited, brought an inner laugh (Hi, @Sam!). And I liked EDDA crossing EDDY.

Much, therefore, to like and admire in the grid for me today.  My day is much better for having done your puzzle, Joe ‚Äì thank you!

I found this to be a totally boring puzzle. I felt as if I were just filling in the blanks, and nothing was exciting about the theme, unlike yesterday's puzzle.I

As for SENT COD, I can remember that being used in advertisements when I was a kid, but couldn't understand how the company collected its money. Was it handed directly to the postman? Always thought that was a strange way of buying things.Closest I ever came was on vacation in a quaint town, either in Minnesota or Arizona, that had a lot of interesting shops. There was a ring that I wanted to buy, but I didn't have enough money with me. The owner, an older gentleman, told me to take the ring and mail him a check when I got home which wouldn't be for several weeks. Having grown up in NY, I was amazed. I asked him why he would do this, and he replied the he knew I would.send the money. Of course I did.
I with Sam Corbin on REUNES in particular‚Ä¶ it seems contrived, but apparently has been in the NYT crossword 7 times in the Shortz era‚Ä¶ this being the third time on a Tuesday.
"One person‚Äôs JETSAM is another‚Äôs flotsam, I suppose." Well done, Sam--using this!

Personally, I‚Äôm just surprised to see all the letters of IRELAND reune in a crossword puzzle. I was thinking it must be a reverse-rebus of Erin or √âire.

The theme actually helped me finish up with STOKES, NEONATE, and TOKYODOME.

TOUCHDOWN!

Liked this puzzle, which seemed just about right for a Tuesday. Cute theme, which I saw early enough to help me get TOKYODOME.

REUNES remains (to me) a dreadful verb, though perhaps there is some (exceeding rare) case in which "reunites" is less preferable.

NEONATE came easily enough, but I must admit that I don't think I've ever heard it in use. Of course, "neonatal" is very common.

Cosine, secant, tangent, sine - come on boys, hold that line. Where was I - oh yeah - an enjoyable Tuesday. Just a bit on the slow side for me, but was close to finishing before I finally caught on to the theme and that's always a nice touch. And, first puzzle find today - a Thursday from January 5, 2012 by Dan Schmiedeler (his only puzzle in the Times). The reveal(s) in that one were two answers that crossed in the very middle of the puzzle, the across clued as "with 21 down, catchphrase that provides a hint to eight answers in this puzzle." And those answers were: ONEFORALL ALLFORONE And some sample clues and answers: "Crowns" ENTHRALLS "Captivates" ENTHRONES "Jane who wrote "In the Shadow of Man" GOODONE "That was funny!" GOODALL "Set up, as software" INSTONE "Fixed" INSTALL Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/5/2012&g=14&d=A Will put another puzzle find in a reply. ....

This was a fairly easy solve for me, but I completely missed the theme part.
Oh well, it was fun anyway.

On the difference between reunites and REUNES:

If someone or -thing is undergoing "reunification" -- a divorced couple or East and West Germany -- they reunite.
If someone is attending a "reunion" -- family or alumni -- she REUNES.
Nevertheless, I agree with Sam that it's an ugly verb, and it's better to say "meets up again" or some such thing.

As for NEONATE instead of infant, baby, or better still "newborn", I think the first sounds more scientific and "hospital-y" and therefore much worse in most situations.

And I wonder how many poets have actually used the word "ETERNE".
Anyone care to research that?
E MINOR would have one flat, not one sharp!

A Tender Hearted Tuesday but the SW did make it interesting.  

"I was floundering to find postage so I SENTCOD".

14A's clue immediately brought to mind a dirty dance song by the rapper Khia. 
If I get caught singing it at work today, this crossword gets the blame!

Oh... and one more puzzle. Again, I've never seen another one like this. Can't imagine having much of a chance at it, other than working it out from the crosses. Anyway - a Sunday from March 8, 1992 by Kevin Boyle with the title: "In other words." Some theme clue and answer examples: "Detritus" FLOTSAMANDJETSAM "Unguentary drosophila" FLYINTHEOINTMENT "Lucubratory pabulum" FOODFORTHOUGHT "Perform peripeteia, in a way" DOANABOUTFACE "Vespertilio from Abaddon" ABATOUTOFHELL "Compendious plus melliferous" SHORTANDSWEET "Puissant spondulicks" ALMIGHTYDOLLAR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/8/1992&g=25&d=A ....

Joe!  Where ya been?  It has been too long since we've had a Deeny puzzle.  Only problem with THIS one is that it was over too soon.

Ah, the EMPIRE State Building...and yet somehow it never occurred to me that NY was "The EMPIRE State."  At one time, Georgia styled itself "The Empire State of the South," while everyone else was determined to call it "The Peach State."  Whatever.  

You don't hear TINKER too often these days, resulting in a dearth of TINKERERs...  Oh, how I wanted to type in "fiddler" JOSH BELL ...though he'd probably give a Master Class rather than "a workshop."  

And for 31A's "Summer temp," I wanted "Nineties" ...but No.

On with the day!

Very nice puzzle!
Sometimes in trying to solve quickly, I put the answer in the wrong squares.  I already had AZTEC for 24 A, and then put the 3D answer in the 2D squares as GLITZY.  Of course, nothing else worked, until I figured out the TO DO theme, and finally solved the NW corner.

Loved RESIDENCES, INTRODUCES, and NEONATE.
Hey, Tuesday PB. Besides the puzzle that involves no interruptions, no distractions (hey..a squirrel!), no typos, and no mis-clicks. Thank you, crossword Gods!

I did not know Popeye's girlfriend spelled her name that way!

Can someone please explain 15a?
My mother made a list every morning. First thing on the list was always "make list." When she finished, she already had one item to cross off. Great way to start the day! üíÉüèª
REALID? As opposed to it formerly being fine to use a fake ID? That one confuses me a little, yet I am not from your continent.

A very crunchy Tuesday for me, and not just because of MUSELI and OATY being two clues that gave me a run for my money. Anyone else have a tough go with the NW corner? I think I like to forget JLO exists, and she never crossed my mind as an option. Nevertheless, we got it done, it just took a lot longer than usual!

Don't know if anyone will be interested in this, but one more surprising answer history search result. Looked up...

INTRODUCES

Today is it's ONLY appearance in a Shortz era puzzle, and... it was only in one pre-Shortz puzzle. And...

INTRODUCE was only in 5 puzzles and all of those were pre-Shortz era. 

Furrowed brow. Must be something about that I'm not getting. 

....
What's easier to get rid of, flotsam or jetsam? Asking for a friend. :)
A rather though Tuesday puzzle. A lot of shortened words NEONATE, etc.. and EDDA?

This crossword was pretty difficult for me, but I still found it fun and thought the theme was well done. Some clues that have multiple answers confused me, like for 42A and 42D I had "desert" and "evades" instead of SAHARA and AVOIDS. Some of it was my own fault though, like me thinking tangent was six letters or deciding that punctual people arrive "on on time".

REUNUES? really?
also... crossing JETSAM x LAOTZU x AZTEC x MUESLI x CLIO was... a choice...

Alexander III was TSAR in St. Petersburg when this E MINOR was written: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ME2vPRNrjvQ&list=RDME2vPRNrjvQ&start_radio=1 But not this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZeFno6ZS0m4&list=RDZeFno6ZS0m4&start_radio=1 *** *** *** Wasn't SENT COD something the Cosa Nostra did as a first warning, before moving on to more severe tactics? (Hi, Sam!)
TOtally DOpe.
Neonate was fine--the neonatal units in hospitals are standard. I've seen eterne used in some poem or other. But reune is just stupid. (Although I appreciated jejune as a a descriptor.)

Ah, so a neonatal unit is where you find a NEONATE!  And a reunion is where you REUNE! Gotta admit, while I‚Äôve never heard these words before, I‚Äôm kind of fascinated to learn they exist. But I don‚Äôt think I can really get behind either one. 

To me, NEONATE is infant‚Äôs pretentious cousin, and REUNE sounds lazy. Just say the last syllable, bro! Because while the mini version of a word may be legit, sometimes it just sounds ridic.

Today my work picks up the pace again after several weeks of feeling spacious and flexible, so I appreciate that I got to start the day with a fun NYT crossword, and learn a few words I had never heard before, including ETERNE, RE√öNE, and NEONATE, of course, but also EDDA. And I learned it‚Äôs Olive OYL, not like the oil!

Reunes bothered me to. The others not.

Jetsam is what you throw overboard so that you don't sink, it makes you lighter in the water. So not the stuff that floats if possible. You toss heavy stuff. Jetsam is unlikely to be floatsam.
EARs are not the only thing popping at my age.  Fantastic Tuesday puzzle!
I share your "Harrumph!", Sam... otherwise, a fun Tuesday puzzle.

Wow, Sam, you ruffled some feathers with your take on reunes etc. For some here the argument starts and ends with "Is it in the dictionary?" and won't listen to anything else. 

I'm glad to hear your honest reaction (and I share it).

OMG what a great puzzle! I didn't get the point until the end but it was fun. As for Sam's comments I agree with the first 2 "kvetches", but I have to admit as a pediatrician a newborn is called a neonate!

A Tuesday Joe Deeney puzzle with ARETHA and Norah EPHRON is more than okay by me. Here's Ms Franklin zooming down the Freeway of Love (in a pink Cadillac) accompainied by Clarence Clemons. https://youtu.be/Ip_pjb5_fgA?si=3NBhnjIs-nRlmE8r Fun Fact--Flotsam and JETSAM are the names of Ursula's eels in Disney's The Little Mermaid.

Oh... one more puzzle find. To say this was unusual would be an understatement. Anyway - A Thursday from March 29, 2012 by Milo Beckman. A fourteen wide puzzle and two grid-spanning entries - one near the top and one near the bottom. TWINKLETWINKLE NOWIKNOWMYABCS Both of those clued as "Words sung to the beginning of 41/39 across." And clue for 39 across: "See 41 across." Clue for 41 across: With 39 across a familiar tune. And those two answers: FAFAMIMIREREDO DODOSOLSOLLALASOL Can't imagine having much of a chance at that one. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/29/2012&g=16&d=A .....
‚ÄúReune‚Äù ?? Really?
Come on New York: no emperors. https://vicendum.fandom.com/wiki/Emperor_of_New_York

Terrific puzzle. In response to Sam‚Äôs complaints, I‚Äôm with her on REUNES, which sounds odd, but ETERNE and NEONATE are familiar. One from poetry and the other from being a mother I guess. 
Thanks Joe Deeney for a delightful Tuesday puzzle with a great theme.

Oh... what the heck - one more puzzle find. A Sunday from June 17, 2018 by Amanda Chung, Karl Ni and Erik Agard with the title: "Tricky Trios." Not easy to describe that one, but I'll try. The theme answers ended with a single letter, which didn't make any sense until you added the letters from the down answer that crossed that ending. One example. I'll put the crossing letters in parentheses: SNAPCRACKLEAND(P) crossed by the down answer PO(P)ULAROPINION And one other - KUKLAFRANDAND(E) crossed by the down answer ROLLI(E) And the other crossing theme answers: WYNKENBLYNKENANDD PETERPAULANDY You can guess at least the string of letters in the down crossings at the end. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/17/2018&g=6&d=D ....

I've never SENTCOD but a few years ago I overnighted lutefisk to a person in Oklahoma...  along with Swedish meatballs and lingonberries. 

Fun puzzle! Didn't get a chance to read comments but I hope others had a good time with it too!!

That's all I got fer ya today!! ‚ò∫Ô∏è
Is it a coincidence that 55across shows up in another puzzle today?
Are ya havin' a bad day, Sam?

An EDDA is not a SAGA.  An Edda is in verse, often with some spiritual implications (about Norse gods and goddesses).  Sagas are in prose and deal largely with historical or pseudo-historical characters.  They are very different.
Reunes? Such a stupid excuse for a word.

@Fact Boy

I knew someone would bring this up, and you didn't disappoint.

@Fact Boy

Snorri Sturluson?  Was that his REALID?

@Fact Boy

Wasn't Snorri Sturluson on Real Househusbands of Dalas√Ωsla?

@Nancy J.
The guy with sleep apnea?

@dutchiris

Ha!

@Isabeau

I never was a fan of REUNES either but (sigh) it‚Äôs standard crossword fare. As a pediatrician I can confirm that NEONATE is absolutely kosher.

@Isabeau

Yeah, that took me by surprise, too.  

"And why is a [Newborn child] a NEONATE, rather than, I don‚Äôt know, a baby?"

Uh, I don't know, because it's a crossword?

Don't mean to be disrespectful, but...üôÑ

@Isabeau

Well in fairness to REUNES there is a difference between REUNE and reunite; I think the former specifically means to hold or attend a formal reunion and not just reunite. I don‚Äôt think you would say a band is reuning (God you can‚Äôt even use it as a participle without cringing)  unless they were actually in a specific reunion show and not just getting back together. Still it‚Äôs one of those words that you feel lazy people use instead of ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre holding a reunion‚Äù. But that‚Äôs the origin of a lot of new words, I suppose. You won‚Äôt catch me ever saying it though.

@Francis

Why is fall called autumn?
Why is a groundhog called a woodchuck?
Why is Meg called Peg?

Because there are sometimes more than one word for the same thing.  That's all.

@Isabeau

That‚Äôs why I love Sam. I suspect the others would keep that to themselves.

@Steve L
And Isabeau is absolutely correct, NEONATE is specifically a newborn baby,  so less than a month, or at most two months if you want to be a little more flexible. I say that because 6-8 weeks is the point at which you start to worry less about a NEONATAL infection if a baby comes to the ER with a fever.

@SP

Yes, I agree the clue is accurate, and Sam's rant is off more than any of her nits are.

38D.  The clue is accurate; a technical term for a newborn is a NEONATE.  "Baby" is indeed too broad.

39A. REUNE(S) is a real verb, and has been for over 150 years, as per the OED.  It's informal, doesn't mean the same as "reunite," although there's some overlap, and it's in current usage.  The clue might have included a marker for jocularity or informality.

59A.  ETERNE is a poetic form of "eternal."  It is poetic; it is archaic; it has existed for seven centuries.  

None of these clues are wrong or bad, they're just not familiar to Sam.  The rant was undeserved, I thought.
@SP I'm a pediatrician too ... maybe this clue will flush us all out lol. Everyday word in our world that I hadn't even thought of as obscure. But maybe it is!

@Francis
The difference is how far the patient's immune system has developed and also what kinds of meds and procedures can be safely used to fight the infection.

@SBK

Oh, ok, thanks!

@Francis - Not a medical person, but I can appreciate that the issues of treating a newborn vs a neonate (til), a 9-month-old and a 12-monther not toddling yet are significantly different.  They grow so much that first year.

@Leontion

I'm not a pediatrician, but I started reading medical books when I was 10 years old. Even took my love of medical terminology, mixed it with my love of foreign language, and became a medical transcriptionist for a while, trying to finally make a clean break from teaching in JHS. But that didn't last, so I return to teaching for the regular paycheck and continued my medical education on the side. Some doctors don't like me. Others appreciate me. Neonate is a favorite word, along with crepitus and borgorygmi.

@Steve L

‚ÄúREUNE(S) is a real verb, and has been for over 150 years, as per the OED.‚Äù

I doubt anybody here is seriously calling ^that^ into question.

‚Äú‚Ä¶and it's in current usage.‚Äù

Now *that* is a bolder claim ü§£

@Times Rita

I know what borgorygmi means, but you might explain it for those who haven't been up in one.

@Francis

Also there are infections you can specifically get from bacteria that the mother may carry‚ÄîGroup B strep for example. So if a baby has a fever below a certain age, we have to be vigilant and do more testing‚Äîblood culture, blood count, maybe a spinal tap, sometimes hospitalize for observation. After the NEONATAL period, not so much. It‚Äôs why I don‚Äôt recommend flying with a NEONATE if you can avoid it, or being around a lot of people; it‚Äôs not like they are so much more likely to get sick or a run a fever, but if they do get a fever from a normal viral illness, you still have to jump through a lot more hoops.
@Times Rita one of my favorites is "intussusception"...  so sibilant!

@Francis @Times Rita

Actually, it's borborygmus, plural borborygmi. Sounds made by the interaction of fluid and gas as the intestines contract to push the contents forward (peristalsis). When the gas gets to the ultimate exit point, it has a different name. Borgorymi are sounds made by the intestines of an alien race, and resistance to them is futile.

@JK
Can we have a bit more information? A one-word declaration, while regal, isn't enlightening.

@SBK
Are you closing in on eeliest?
JK means Just Kidding. Relax

@retired, with cat
Eeliest is beyond my hopes.

@SBK
Not at all; you have no competition that I can see. You alone own eelianism in this forum, and possibly throughout the universe.

@retired, with cat
By the way, I used ‚Äúeelianism‚Äù as a term of respect for eels‚Äô inherent beingness, as opposed to ‚Äúeeliness‚Äù that would imply slinking  out of accountability, for what it‚Äôs worth.

@retired, with cat
Consistent with my earlier posts,  I feel that if we must refer to the state of being like an eel, it should be the honest --if uncomplimentary -- 'eeliness'. 'Eelianism' sounds as if the eels have a choice to engage. Their sliminess is involuntary.

@Mr Dave

There‚Äôs always someone who insists the dictionary is wrong.

@Steve L

You missed the point. Think about it some more.

@Bay Area Native YES. Strunk & White use the example that a certain zoo COMPRISES the beasts of the savannah, the major predators, and small mammals. @Laura Whitaker

Yes, that was my understanding back when I cared about such things.  "comprises" and "is composed of" are the two opposites in the phrase.

@Bay Area Native

OK, let me rephrase.

@Bay Area Native From Merriam-Webster: Did you know? The earliest meaning of comprise, "to be made up of" (as in "a team comprising nine players"), is sometimes regarded as the word's only correct use. However, this grammatical prescription denies a well-established sense of the word: "to compose or constitute" (as in "the nine players who comprise the team"). Until relatively recently, this sense appeared mostly in scientific writing, but current evidence shows that it is now somewhat more common in general use than the word's other meanings. You might be most familiar with this disputed use in the passive construction, "to be comprised of" (as in "a team comprised of nine players"). Apologies to the haters: a single sense simply can‚Äôt comprise comprise. Lest you say M-W doesn't count, here's what Collins says: https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/be-confined This is a usage in mid-change, actually closer to acceptance than not. Older people who hew to what their teacher taught them are going to push back, while everyone else will go with the flow. English changes. It doesn't sound or look like Beowulf, Chaucer, Shakespeare or even Dickens.
@Bay Area Native Why can't you have it both ways?  There are other words in English that have opposite definitions -- cleave, clip, drop, dust, etc.  Contronyms are fun!

The bigger point, however, is not that these three aren't 
"real words", but rather that they appear in crosswords much more than they appear in "real life".

It would be better if constructors could limit (if not eliminate) their use of such "crossword-ese".

@The X-Phile

Keats, Shakespeare, Browning‚Ä¶

@The X-Phile What makes you call a word like ETERNE crosswordese is that you've seen it more in crosswords than in real life. What this tells me mostly is that you don't read a lot of poetry. (If you haven't seen NEONATE out there in real life, you haven't been around too many just-born infants.) Look at it from the point of view of a constructor. First of all, it's made up completely of the Wheel of Fortune letters: E, T, R, and N. That makes it extremely useful. Secondly, there's no constructor who uses this word excessively. According to xwordinfo.com, it's the first time Joe Deeney has ever used it. The time before that, on 12/8/24, it was the first time John Kugelman used it. And so on back until 2013. Crossword greats like Barry C. Silk, Brendan Emmett Quigley, Fred Piscop, Matt Gaffney, Patrick Berry, Paula Gamache, and others, have all used it. Once each. Probably less frequently than Keats, Shakespeare and Browning did. In fact, in all of the Modern Era, you'll only find two constructors who have used ETERNE twice: Matt Ginsberg (once in a co-construction) and Richard Silvestri (and that was last millennium). So I'd bet that constructors are limiting their use of crosswordese. It's just that there have been a lot of puzzles out there. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Finder?w=ETERNE
